content: The Act may be cited as the "Salute to Veterans and the Armed Forces Act of 2003" and includes a table of contents. The "Salute to Veterans and the Armed Forces Act of 2003" includes provisions for full payment of retired pay and compensation to disabled military retirees, repeal of dependency and indemnity compensation offset for survivor benefits, increase in educational assistance for Selected Reserve members, application of index based on higher learning costs, one-time bonus for service in Operation Iraqi Freedom or Operation Enduring Freedom, authorization of additional funding for veterans medical care, and interim payments for delayed veterans claims. The "Salute to Veterans and the Armed Forces Act of 2003" includes provisions for full payment of retired pay and compensation to disabled military retirees, repeal of dependency and indemnity compensation offset for survivor benefits, increase in educational assistance for Selected Reserve members, one-time bonus for service in Operation Iraqi Freedom or Operation Enduring Freedom, authorization of additional funding for veterans medical care, and retention of 38.6 percent top individual income tax rate. SEC. 2. FULL PAYMENT OF BOTH RETIRED PAY AND COMPENSATION TO DISABLED MILITARY RETIREES. Section 1414 of title 10, United States Code, is amended to allow members eligible for retired pay and veterans' disability compensation to receive both without regard to certain sections. Retired pay of chapter 61 career retirees with 20 years or more of service can be subject to reduction. Members eligible for retired pay and veterans' disability compensation can receive both without regard to certain sections. Retired pay of chapter 61 career retirees with 20 years or more of service may be subject to reduction under specific conditions. Repeal of special compensation programs in title 38, with corresponding clerical amendment. The section discusses the payment of retired pay and veterans' disability compensation for members eligible for retired pay with service-connected disabilities. The effective date for the amendments is specified, and retroactive benefits are not allowed before the effective date. Additionally, there is a repeal of the dependency and indemnity compensation offset from survivor benefit plan surviving spouse annuities. The repeal of certain sections of title 10, United States Code is effective from October 1, 2003, or the date of enactment. Surviving spouses receiving SBP annuities before the effective date may need to repay previously refunded amounts. The repayment of SBP annuity refunds is determined based on the surviving spouse's life expectancy. The amount to be repaid is calculated proportionally to the refund received. SBP annuity refers to an annuity under the program established in title 10, United States Code. SBP retired pay refund is a refund under section 1450 of title 10, United States Code. The curr_chunk refers to a specific section (e) of title 10, United States Code. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN AMOUNT OF BASIC EDUCATIONAL ASSISTANCE FOR MEMBERS OF THE SELECTED RESERVE. The amount of educational assistance for members of the Selected Reserve is increased, with changes in allowance amounts effective from October 1, 2004. For fiscal year 2004, different allowance amounts apply. The educational assistance for Selected Reserve members is increased, with allowance amount changes effective from October 1, 2004. No adjustment for rates of basic educational assistance for fiscal years 2004 and 2005. SEC. 5. APPLICATION OF INDEX BASED ON COSTS OF HIGHER LEARNING. The Secretary of Defense is required to adjust rates for tuition and expenses at public institutions of higher learning based on cost increases, in consultation with the Secretary of Education. The Secretary of Defense adjusts rates for tuition and expenses at public institutions of higher learning based on cost increases. Determinations made under this adjustment take effect on October 1 of the year and apply to educational assistance allowances for the fiscal year. The Secretary publishes the average monthly costs of tuition and expenses each year in the Federal Register. Additionally, a conforming amendment to Section 3015(h) of title 38, United States Code, applies to fiscal years beginning on or after October 1, 2005. SEC. 6. ONE-TIME BONUS FOR CERTAIN SERVICE IN CONNECTION WITH OPERATION IRAQI FREEDOM OR OPERATION ENDURING FREEDOM. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Homeland Security shall provide a $1,000 bonus to eligible members of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, and Coast Guard who served during Operation Iraqi Freedom or Operation Enduring Freedom and met the criteria for special pay for duty in hostile fire or imminent danger. The bonus amount for eligible members is $1,000, and a member can only receive one bonus payment. Authorization of additional funding of $1,000,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2013 for Veterans Medical Care to ensure veterans receive healthcare within 30 days. Interim payments for certain veterans claims when decisions are delayed after remand for expedited consideration. Interim benefits of $500 per month are provided to claimants under remanded cases if the Secretary fails to make a decision within 180 days. These payments start after the 180-day period and continue until a final decision is reached on the claim. When a claim with interim benefits is finally decided, the amounts paid are considered as advance payment of benefits owed. If benefits are awarded, interim payments cover the period before the final decision. If benefits are not awarded, interim payments are not considered as overpayment. Section 5320 of title 38, United States Code, applies to decisions remanded by the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims or the Board of Veterans' Appeals after the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a report to Congress within six months outlining measures to expedite the processing of remanded claims for veterans benefits. Additionally, there is a prohibition on increasing medication copayments for veterans and imposing healthcare enrollment fees for veterans. During the specified period after the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs is prohibited from increasing medication copayments and implementing enrollment fees for veterans in the healthcare system. Section 1142 of title 10, United States Code, is amended to include information on accessing veterans benefits and employment opportunities on the final pay stub for members separating from active duty. This amendment applies to individuals leaving the Armed Forces after 60 days from the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there is a provision prohibiting the Secretary of Veterans Affairs from increasing medication copayments and implementing enrollment fees for veterans in the healthcare system. The amendment to Section 7722(c) of title 38, United States Code, requires information on how to apply for benefits and specific details for distinct beneficiary populations. Additionally, a new section 7728 mandates the Secretary to prepare an annual outreach plan for conducting outreach activities. The Secretary is required to prepare an annual outreach plan for conducting outreach activities to identify veterans not enrolled for benefits, inform veterans of changes in benefit programs, and consult with various organizations and individuals. The annual report must include details on the effectiveness of the outreach plan for assisting veterans in transitioning to civilian life. SEC. 12. RETENTION OF 38.6 PERCENT TOP INDIVIDUAL INCOME TAX RATE. The top individual income tax rate is amended to 38.6% for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002.
